I know nobody cares or will read this thread but point of order: I would be a horrendous Commissioner. It's just amid all the point-scoring, vendettas and piss-taking, I would deal with complaints properly. That was what I was trying to say.
But I'm never going to be Commissioner and we're never going to have people like Chris Graham or Liz France in the job again. It's going to be a procession of people wanting to hit the big time.

Of course, Liz Denham poisoned them forever by making it seem like they were a big international player constantly tackling big issues and so John Edwards has come for his slice of that action. But if they prioritised complaints, the ripples would be small but endless.

Apropos of nothing in particular, I think the ICO should be a much more mundane organisation, concerned with individual complaints and smaller-scale issues. I think they'd get more done and have a more positive impact on data protection and wider society.
@MissIG_Geek I want some heads on spikes. Even if I'm wrong about big tech and the ICO's ability to go after them, they could do both, rather than the tepid bullshit you originally reacted to.

@MissIG_Geek No disagreement there, but I'm still also talking about individual householders. I know some of the complaints ICO has had and ignored because I know the people who have made them. These are data controllers because of how they've deployed the cameras, and they're breaching GDPR.

@MissIG_Geek Fair enough. We disagree about big tech harm and I suspect that's irresolvable. However, dodging that, if we think of what ICO can do, I'd argue that they can have more impact on domestic CCTV (i.e. pick a few bad cases and cause some pain) than anything they can do to big tech.

@MissIG_Geek Not to be pedantic, but this isn’t what your first tweet said, hence my reply. The biggest threat isn’t Amazon or Google; it’s people in the real world with malign intent. Big tech risk is smaller, and ICO should tackle the abuse first. Admittedly, they won’t do either.

@MissIG_Geek If your neighbour is using the device to harass you, I disagree. A person I know who is suffering from this is less concerned about Google than an abusive person who lives in close proximity to them.

To win a #GDPR compensation case, you need evidence of a contravention, not an incident. Then you need to show evidence of the damage. If the claimant loses here and ends up on the hook for costs, that's a disaster for them. Have they been mis-sold a dream of easy compensation?

There's a compensation culture built on PPI mis-selling. Payouts were common and rightly so. GDPR isn't the same. Lawyers across the UK are touting Data Protection claims as a way to get easy money. When they hit the courts, they often get found out. There will be consequences.

I was heavily in debt decades ago, and did a lot of loan-hopping to juggle debts I couldn't afford to pay off (thank you, lucrative second job as data protection trainer). I remember companies trying to sell me PPI policies I plainly would never be able to claim on.

Then there's the damage part. The court pointed out that her name and address are freely available by https://t.co/4iz9O3Ascy and https://t.co/M7Gmezk3V5, and no attempt was made to mask her address in the current case. This will not help the credibility of the claim.

The first problem is that suing under GDPR means that she still needs to prove a contravention - you can't be compensated for the consequences of an accident under Data Protection (unpopular opinion, I believe in accidents). You need an underlying non-compliance.

There's a complication. The claimant moved to escape an abusive relationship some years before, and stated that what she admitted was the unlikely possibility of her address falling into her former partner's hands caused her psychological distress.

The case doesn't get dismissed, just relegated to the Small Claims Court, but it's another example of a weak-sounding case, a small incident bolstered by distress claims. The claimant's address was accidentally sent to the wrong person; the errant email was deleted within hours.

It's not exactly Google vs Lloyd, but #GDPR / DPA compensation cases aren't currently having a good run. this case from October sees a rather withering response to a claim against a housing organisation for an incident apparently based on human error. https://t.co/s74gtCjVaT

They've not updated the website's multiple references to Lloyd yet, but whether this case goes ahead will be an interesting indicator of Lloyd's impact. Will the funders still want to pay to see it through?

This claim against TikTok will be one to watch to see what happens to big data cases in the light of Google vs Lloyd. There are some differences; it's #GDPR not DPA 1998, and the use of kids' data might be a more compelling case than the random web users. https://t.co/aQTNrvH9Sr
